clinical_study.brief_title: Airway Pressure Release Ventilation as a Preventative Strategy
clinical_study.official_title: Airway Pressure Release Ventilation as a Preventative Strategy in Patients at Risk for Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome

lead_sponsor.agency: Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center

clinical_study.source: Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center

brief_summary.textblock: The early initiation of Airway Pressure Release Ventilation in multi-system trauma patients decreases the incidence and severity of acute lung injury and Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome and allows faster recovery of lung function.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Principal Investigator left the institution before subjects were enrolled

primary_outcome.measure: The primary endpoint will be the number of ventilator-free days.

secondary_outcome.measure: effects of ventilator mode on ventilation

intervention.description: Airway Pressure Release Ventilation (APRV) also known as Bi-Vent or Bi-Level ventilation is a time-cycled, pressure-limited mode of ventilation that allows spontaneous respiration throughout the ventilator cycle.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Trauma patients age 16 or older
- Trauma patients requiring ventilatory support within 48 hours of injury
- Those with anticipated ventilatory support ≥ 24 hours
- Subject or authorized representative (AR) has signed an informed consent form (ICF)
- Subjects age 16 or 17 who have signed an assent document and/or AR has signed an ICF
Exclusion Criteria:
- Significant chronic lung disease defined as lung pathology requiring home O2 use
- Chronic heart disease defined as NYHC III or higher
- Persistent bronchopulmonary air leak
- Contraindications to permissive hypercapnia (ex. Intracerebral bleeding, brain tumor, fulminant hepatic failure, and hemodynamic instability)
- Pulmonary artery occlusion pressures ≥ 18 mmHg
- Severe neurologic injury that may prevent the patient from having a reasonable opportunity for weaning as determined by the clinical study team
- Immuno-compromised patients secondary to drugs or disease
- Neuromuscular disease that impairs ability to ventilate spontaneously (ex. Spinal injury at or above C5, ALS, Guillain-Barre syndrome, Myasthenia Gravis)
- History of pneumonectomy
- Pregnancy
- Burns with TBSA ≥ 20%
- Acute MI as the cause of ALI/ARDS
- All other contraindications to APRV
- Patients who cannot be randomized within 12 hours of intubation
